column1: Before surgery, your child will receive general anesthesia.
During surgery, your child's surgeon will use steel rods, hooks, screws, or other metal devices to straighten your child's spine and support the bones of the spine.
This cut may be in your child's back, chest, or both places.
The surgeon may also do the procedure using a special video camera.
The surgeon makes a cut in your child's chest, deflates a lung, and usually removes a rib.
- The joints between the different vertebrae (the bones of the spine) will be taken out.
- If the curve is severe enough, scoliosis affects your child's breathing.

Surgery is usually recommended for the following children and adolescents with scoliosis of unknown cause (idiopathic scoliosis): - All young people whose skeletons have matured, and who have a curve greater than 45 degrees.
- Gallstones or pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) - Intestinal obstruction (blockage).
- A metal hook placed in the spine may move a little.
- New spine problems may develop, especially in children who have surgery before their spine has stopped growing.
These include aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn).
If the surgery involved a surgical cut in the chest, your child may have a tube in the chest to drain fluid buildup.
